unnormalised: I've seen a lot of questions about dosages and measurements in medicine. It can get pretty confusing, especially with different units floating around. Let's try to break it down a bit, focusing on common ones used in India.
normalised: I have seen a lot of questions about dosages and measurements in medicine. It can get pretty confusing, especially with different units floating around. Let us try to break it down a bit, focusing on common ones used in India.

unnormalised: First off, volume. You'll often see liquid medications measured in mL (milliliters). For example, a cough syrup might say "take 5 mL three times a day." Sometimes, you'll also encounter cc, which stands for cubic centimeters. Good to remember that 1 mL is equal to 1 cc, so don't get too worked up if you see either one! Doses for injectables are also given in mL (like a vaccine may require 0.5 mL dose).
normalised: First off, volume. You will often see liquid medications measured in milliliter. For example, a cough syrup might say "take five milliliter three times a day." Sometimes, you will also encounter c c, which stands for cubic centimeter. Good to remember that one milliliter is equal to one c c, so don't get too worked up if you see either one! Doses for injectables are also given in milliliter (like a vaccine may require zero point five milliliter dose).

unnormalised: Then there's weight, primarily used for solid medications like tablets or capsules. Here, mg (milligrams) and g (grams) are your go-to units. A common painkiller, say, Paracetamol, is frequently available in 500 mg tablets. And remember, 1000 mg makes 1 g. Sometimes doctors might prescribe something in mcg (micrograms) like Vitamin B12 - and there are 1,000,000 mcg in 1 g. Conversions become very very important here.
normalised: Then there is weight, primarily used for solid medications like tablets or capsules. Here, milligram and gram are your go to units. A common painkiller, say, Paracetamol, is frequently available in five hundred milligram tablets. And remember, one thousand milligram makes one gram. Sometimes doctors might prescribe something in microgram like Vitamin B twelve, and there are one million microgram in one gram. Conversions become very very important here.

unnormalised: Beyond the basic units, you might hear about "IU," which stands for International Units. These are typically for vitamins and certain hormones where the measurement isn't as straightforward as weight or volume. For example, Vitamin D dosage is often specified in IUs, like "60,000 IU once a week." Don't get it confused with just plain numbers either - those are just counts.
normalised: Beyond the basic units, you might hear about "I U," which stands for International Units. These are typically for vitamins and certain hormones where the measurement is not as straightforward as weight or volume. For example, Vitamin D dosage is often specified in I Us, like "sixty thousand I U once a week." Don't get it confused with just plain numbers either, those are just counts.

unnormalised: It's crucial to always follow your doctor’s instructions exactly and to double-check the units on the medication label. When in doubt, always ask your pharmacist or doctor to clarify! Misunderstanding units can lead to serious health consequences. Never assume and always verify.
